channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: Washington, D.C. residents weigh in on crime amid Trump's federal takeover
item.description: Perspectives on crime in Washington, D.C., differ depending on where you are. Overall, though, residents seem to think President Trump's approach isn't the right one.

item.title: Ukrainians want an end to Russia's war, but remain wary of the Trump-Putin meeting
item.description: Many Ukrainians want an end to years of war, but are reacting with wariness to President Trump's upcoming meeting with Russia's Vladimir Putin.

item.title: Argentina is an example of what happens when a country manipulates inflation data
item.description: Trump fired the Bureau of Labor Statistics head. In Argentina, the government manipulated the inflation rate. Economists went rogue to calculate the real rate, and people lost trust in the numbers.

item.title: Trump's move to end TPS rattles health care workers who tend to the sick and elderly
item.description: The Trump administration's decision to end Temporary Protected Status for people from a number of countries has rattled health care workers who tend to the sick and elderly.

item.title: President Trump is upending global trade as we know it. What comes next?
item.description: NPR's Ari Shapiro speaks with former US trade representative and Council on Foreign Relations President Michael Froman about how global trade moves forward in the midst of President Trump's tariffs.

item.title: Ants could teach humans a thing or two about teamwork
item.description: When more humans participate in a game of tug-o-war, each individual puts in less effort. But the opposite is true in weaver ants, according to new research in the journal Current Biology.

item.title: A new antiwar camp is emerging in Israel. It includes soldiers and former soldiers
item.description: Within Israel's prime minister pushing for a full occupation of Gaza, some of Israel's exhausted soldiers are pushing back and calling for an end to the war.

item.title: Boston Public Library aims to increase access to a vast historic archive using AI
item.description: The Boston Public Library is launching a project in collaboration with Harvard University and OpenAI to increase public access to hundreds of thousands of historically significant documents.

item.title: Working with D.C.'s unhoused population
item.description: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with Dr. Catherine Crosland, who works directly with people experiencing homelessness in Washington, D.C., following President Trump's law enforcement actions in the capital.

item.title: Daniel Dae Kim on what helps ground him as an actor and his new TV series, 'Butterfly'
item.description: NPR's Ailsa Chang talks to actor Daniel Dae Kim about his upbringing and training for action scenes in his new TV series, Butterfly.
